text: I'm seeing the notebook page itself become fairly unresponsive after working with it a while, particularly when generating plots over and over. Only affects the one notebook, others stay responsive. I'm curious if there's a loop running on the notebook process that's getting stretched too thin, or perhaps the script in the browser? I can investigate if I know where to look.

attachments.fallback: [February 7th, 2021 6:41 PM] joshday: Okay all, I think this is the strangest error I've run into while coding in Julia.  When `using Pluto` inside a notebook, the notebook freezes without errors after it hits exactly 10 `@info` statements.  Could someone test this and let me know that I'm not crazy?

text: 1GB for a web browser is normal, but you could use the process manager _inside chrome_ to see the memory usage _per tab_, check if that increases

text: to answer your original question: if it ‘feels’ unresponsive (when typing, scrolling, hovering) then that’s not because of julia but because of the browser scripts

elements.text: to answer your original question: if it ‘feels’ unresponsive (when typing, scrolling, hovering) then that’s not because of julia but because of the browser scripts

text: My browser tab occasionally crashes when I make a change that causes many Plots to be redrawn, reloading the page recovers the running session though

elements.text: My browser tab occasionally crashes when I make a change that causes many Plots to be redrawn, reloading the page recovers the running session though

text: It seems that a single plot is causing the javascript heap to increase by 500 MB. But why? Shouldn't the only data communicated and stored by the Pluto notebook webpage be just the final plot image (which is just 512x256)?

elements.text: It seems that a single plot is causing the javascript heap to increase by 500 MB. But why? Shouldn't the only data communicated and stored by the Pluto notebook webpage be just the final plot image (which is just 512x256)?

text: A script called "msgpack-es" seems to be doing the bulk of the work during memory accumulation.

elements.text: A script called "msgpack-es" seems to be doing the bulk of the work during memory accumulation.
